title: U.S. stocks tick higher as investors await earnings wave and Fed decision
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA was off 112 points, or 0.4%, at 32,011.

* The S&P 500 SPX rose 7 points, or 0.2%, to 3,969.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP shed 18 points, or 0.2%, to trade at11,810.

The Dow last week rose 2%, while the S&P 500 gained 2.6% and the Nasdaq Composite advanced 3.3%. The Russell 2000 index RUT of small cap stocks is up 5.8% so far in July.

What's driving markets

Traders were positive early on Monday, though appeared reluctant to build bold positions before a big batch of corporate earnings that could shape market sentiment in the short term.

For the new week there will be 175 S&P 500 companies reporting, including big beasts like Apple AAPL, Alphabet GOOGL, Microsoft MSFT and Amazon AMZN, though the action doesn't pick up again until Tuesday.

The S&P 500 is down 16.9% for the year to date but has climbed 8% from its 52-week low hit in mid-June, with sentiment underpinned of late by a corporate reporting season that has proved better than some had feared.

"Earnings season has been mixed, but boring is beautiful," said Stephen Innes, managing partner at SPI Asset Management.

See: Bear-market bottom for U.S. stocks? What the pros say as S&P 500 tests 4,000

With 21% of S&P 500 companies having reported, the second quarter blended earnings growth rate for the benchmark index is 4.8%, according to John Butters, senior earnings analyst at FactSet.

"If 4.8% is the actual growth rate for the quarter, it will mark the lowest earnings growth rate reported by the index since Q4 2020 (4.0%)," said Butters. However, "68% of S&P 500 companies have reported a positive EPS surprise and 65% of S&P 500 companies have reported a positive revenue surprise," he added.

The market's forward 12-month P/E ratio is 16.7, below the 10-year average of 17.0, according to FactSet, a pullback that is supporting valuations.

The looming Federal Reserve rate decision on Wednesday provided another reason for caution. The central bank is expected to raise borrowing costs by 75 basis points to a range of 2.25% to 2.50%, but investors will be keen to hear about how the Fed sees the pace of future hikes.

"The pace of hikes remains uncertain as we get into the fall. If labor market data starts to soften we can expect the Fed's attention to once again switch to its dual mandate. But if inflation remains stubbornly high, then the Fed may continue to hike even if a recession is imminent," said Solita Marcelli, chief investment officer for the Americas at UBS Global Wealth Management, in a note.

"This uncertainty is likely to keep volatility elevated. The stock market is likely to remain range bound until the Fed pivots, or we get a reacceleration in business activity," Marcelli said.

Read: Will the Federal Reserve snuff out a stock-market bounce? What investors will be watching.

Ahead of the Fed, the 10-year Treasury yield BX:TMUBMUSD10Y was up 3 basis points to 2.783% and ICE Dollar index DXY is barely changed at 106.70.

Companies in focus

* Shares of Weber Inc. WEBR tumbled 21.7% after the grill maker issued a sales warning for its third quarter and announced the departure of its chief executive Chris Scherzinger.

* Tesla Inc. TSLA disclosed in its latest 10-Q filing Monday that it received a second subpoena from the Securities and Exchange Commission asking the company to provide information on its "governance processes around compliance with the SEC settlement" related to Chief Executive Elon Musk's 2018 tweet about taking the company private at $420 a share. Tesla shares were up 0.2%.

See: Elon Musk denies alleged affair with Google co-founder Sergey Brin's wife as 'total bs'

How are other assets faring

* U.S. crude futures CL.1 rose 1.5% to $96/12 a barrel, having at one point touched a five-month low around $91, as traders worried about slowing demand as economies sputter.

* Bitcoin BTCUSD fell 3.1% to $21,923 and gold GC00 edged down 0.2% to $1,723.60 an ounce.

* Hong Kong's Hang Seng HK:HSI ended 0.2% lower, while the Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMP shed 0.6% and Japan's Nikkei 225 JP:NIK ended with a drop of 0.8%. In Europe, the Stoxx 600 XX:SXXP advanced 0.2%, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX was up 0.3%.

U.S. stocks tick higher as investors await earnings wave and Fed decision
